awd_titl_txt: CRISP Type 2: Identification and Control of Uncertain, Highly Interdependent Processes Involving Humans with Applications to Resilient Emergency Health Response
awd_abstract_narration:
The growing pace of urbanization, particularly along coasts, in conjunction with non-robust infrastructures with poorly understood interdependencies, will make major weather events, intensified by warming oceans and rising sea level, more likely to turn into disasters in the near future. Superstorm Sandy provided a particularly poignant example of this situation. This Critical Resilient Interdependent Infrastructure Systems and Processes (CRISP) Type 2 grant will pioneer a new approach to enable communities to withstand and bounce back quickly from hazards. This will be accomplished through a new paradigm of proactive resiliency through "prediction, intervention and adaptation," as opposed to the current reactive cycle of discovery, recovery and redesign. A unique feature of the this research is the integration of engineering (electrical, industrial, civil), computer science and social science strategies for achieving resilience over the short and long term. Education is proactively integrated into this project, starting with summer STEM courses for urban middle school students and continuing at the college level with a multi-disciplinary program that uses the central metaphor of resilient communities to link a full range of distinct subjects. This approach will help broaden participation of underrepresented groups in research and substantially transform engineering and social sciences education.

This research seeks to develop a comprehensive framework for designing and operating resilient communities by modeling them as partially engineered networked cyber-physical-human systems. The ultimate goal is to develop a synthesis framework for such systems, capable of guaranteeing minimum levels of performance and rapid recovery of functionality in the face of disruptions. This goal will be accomplished by recasting the problem in the context of data-driven identification and control of processes represented by dynamical graphical models, where both the nodes and interconnecting edges are dynamical systems that encapsulate the cyber-physical and human aspects of the problem. The approach allows for treating all aspects of the problem in a unified way, leveraging recent advances in optimization, networked control and agent based modeling to obtain scalable, computationally tractable solutions. Salient features of this framework include the integration of agent based modeling of human responses into a chance constrained optimization framework that identifies strategies to optimize resilience, the use of data driven models to extract actionable information from extremely large data sets, and purposeful manipulation of system-wide components, enabled by novel fuse-based design techniques. The resulting framework will be tested using a scenario involving four systems critical to maintaining minimum levels of emergency medicine: power, communications, critical goods supply chain and built environment.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Summary: This CRISP Type 2 grant pioneered a new approach to enable communities to withstand and bounce back quickly from hazards. This was accomplished through a new paradigm of proactive resiliency through "prediction, intervention and adaptation," as opposed to the current reactive cycle of discovery, recovery and redesign. A unique feature of this project was the integration of engineering (electrical, industrial, civil), computer science and social science strategies for achieving resilience over the short and long term.

Intellectual Merit: This research developed a comprehensive framework for designing and operating resilient communities by modeling them as partially engineered networked cyber-physical-human systems. With a focus on  emergency management strategies for vulnerable populations, particularly as they relate to the communications and power grid, we developed a framework for   joint decision-making  on emergency services deployment and load shedding. These decisions are based on using actual hurricane profiles and models of human behavior to characterize the impact of deploying a strategic joint-decision policy,  rather than a decoupled decision system (similar to existing systems).  Testing using models derived from data collected from several hurricanes, showed that this holistic approach substantially decreases the impact of power outages on vulnerable populations, as decisions are simultaneously made on load shedding practices and EMS deployment accounting for locations of these vulnerable populations, fragility of the built environment and likely models of human responses.   In addition to the contributions to resilient control of interconnected systems involving humans, this project made the following contributions to each of the constituent disciplines:
Social science:  Development of a computational model of hurricane evacuation behavior that predicted whether people would evacuate or stay in their home and identified factors that influence that behavior.  

Civil Infrastructure Modeling:  Exploited a combination of machine learning and finite element analysis to develop  collapse fragility curves of electrical transmission and communication towers.

Network Science: Development of a framework to analyze the robustness of interconnected networks to inhomogeneous failures.  

Power systems: A new,  computationally efficient method for improving resilience of power grids by strategic placement of static volt-ampere-reactive (VAR) compensators.

Decision making under uncertainty:  Development of verifiable decision-making algorithms for complex, interconnected dynamical systems where the dynamics and initial conditions are only partially known.

Emergency services management:  A new extended  Maximal Expected Coverage Location Model  that takes into consideration the topology of the power grid and load shedding strategies. 

Machine learning: Development of an interpretable  deep learning based architecture to predict future values of time-series. This new deep network is substantially more compact than existing ones, hence requiring less training time, while outperforming them in terms of classification and prediction errors.

Broader impact: Vulnerable populations including older adults continue to be disproportionately impacted during extreme events.  Studies point to the expectation for growing sociodemographic inequities in the effects of disasters with accelerations in climate change.  In light of these trends, crises or disasters that cause power outages (e.g., hurricanes, floods, heatwaves) are of present significant danger to those dependent on at-home electricity medical equipment. The joint life-lines management framework developed under this grant can substantially  decrease the impact of  hazards on  vulnerable populations.

This project provided opportunities for research and teaching in the fields that contribute to the project (Computer Science, Civil, Electrical and Industrial Engineering, Optimization, Social and Behavioral Science). This is expected to contribute to the future work force who will require skills in Engineering, Computer Science and Social and Behavioral Science. Additionally, through their work on this project, these students have expanded their knowledge and expertise in exploring the multi-dimensional challenges of emergency response, including in the COVID-19 crisis, and received training in the interdisciplinary viewpoint that is critical to response to future crises. 


Last Modified: 11/29/2021
Modified by: Mario Sznaier

    Interconnected Systems
  • Jointly optimizing life-line management leads to a polynomial optimization problem that can be solved using sum-of-squares techniques.
    Mario Sznaier, Northeastern
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Mario Sznaier
    Joint optimization
  • Fragility analysis of the power grid in Massachusetts showing the probability of failure.
    Jerome Hajjar, Northeastern
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Mario Sznaier
    Fragility analysis of Massachusetts
  • Managing interconnecting life-lines. Load shedding decisions are made taking into account their impact on communications and health care
    Ali Abur
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Mario Sznaier
    Managing interconnected life-lines.
  • A Markov Decision Process to predict human evacuation decisions.
    Stacy Marsella

    Human model

Summary: This CRISP Type 2 grant pioneered a new approach to enable communities to withstand and bounce back quickly from hazards. This was accomplished through a new paradigm of proactive resiliency through "prediction, intervention and adaptation," as opposed to the current reactive cycle of discovery, recovery and redesign. A unique feature of this project was the integration of engineering (electrical, industrial, civil), computer science and social science strategies for achieving resilience over the short and long term.

Intellectual Merit: This research developed a comprehensive framework for designing and operating resilient communities by modeling them as partially engineered networked cyber-physical-human systems. With a focus on  emergency management strategies for vulnerable populations, particularly as they relate to the communications and power grid, we developed a framework for   joint decision-making  on emergency services deployment and load shedding. These decisions are based on using actual hurricane profiles and models of human behavior to characterize the impact of deploying a strategic joint-decision policy,  rather than a decoupled decision system (similar to existing systems).  Testing using models derived from data collected from several hurricanes, showed that this holistic approach substantially decreases the impact of power outages on vulnerable populations, as decisions are simultaneously made on load shedding practices and EMS deployment accounting for locations of these vulnerable populations, fragility of the built environment and likely models of human responses. Machine learning: Development of an interpretable  deep learning based architecture to predict future values of time-series. This new deep network is substantially more compact than existing ones, hence requiring less training time, while outperforming them in terms of classification and prediction errors.

Broader impact: Vulnerable populations including older adults continue to be disproportionately impacted during extreme events. In light of these trends, crises or disasters that cause power outages (e.g., hurricanes, floods, heatwaves) are of present significant danger to those dependent on at-home electricity medical equipment. The joint life-lines management framework developed under this grant can substantially  decrease the impact of  hazards on  vulnerable populations.

This project provided opportunities for research and teaching in the fields that contribute to the project (Computer Science, Civil, Electrical and Industrial Engineering, Optimization, Social and Behavioral Science).
